metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (automatic weather station of Zhangye wetland station, 2014)
metadata.description:
The data set contains meteorological observation data of zhangye wetland station in the middle reaches of heihe hydrometeorological observation network from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014.The site is located in zhangye national wetland park in gansu province.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 100.4464E, 38.9751N, and altitude is 1460m.Air temperature and relative humidity sensors are set up at 5m and 10m, facing due north.The barometer is installed at 2m;The inverted bucket rain gauge is installed at 10m;The wind speed sensor is set up at 5m and 10m, and the wind direction sensor is set up at 10m, facing due north.The four-component radiometer is installed at 6m, facing due south;The two infrared thermometers are installed at the position of 6m, facing south, and the probe is facing vertically downward.The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm on the surface and 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm and 40cm underground, in the south due to 2m from the meteorological tower.The soil hot flow plates (3) are successively buried in the ground 6cm;Four photosynthetic radiometers are installed above and inside the canopy respectively. The upper part of the canopy is installed at 6m (one probe vertically up and one probe vertically down), and the upper part of the canopy is installed at 0.25m (one probe vertically up and one probe vertically down), facing due south.
Observation items are: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5m RH_5m Ta_10m, RH_10m) (unit: c, percentage), pressure (Press) (unit: hundred mpa), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), wind speed (WS_5m, WS_10m) (unit: m/s), wind (WD_10m) (unit: degrees), the radiation of four component (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit:Degrees Celsius), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (unit: watts per square meter), soil temperature (Ts_0cm Ts_2cm Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm) (unit: c), the canopy on the up and down photosynthetic active radiation (PAR_U_up, PAR_U_down) (unit: second micromoles/m2) and up and down under canopy photosynthetic active radiation (PAR_D_up, PAR_D_down) (unit: second micromoles/m2).
Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) eliminate the moments with duplicate records;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked by red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) the format of date and time is uniform, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2014-6-10-10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
Please refer to Li et al.(2013) for hydrometeorological network or site information, and Liu et al.(2011) for observation data processing.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Verification.Question: Is the TSEB model suitable for estimating evapotranspiration in irrigated agricultural areas with strong advective conditions?

Disjunctive.Question: Do datasets in the field of oasis-desert interactions primarily originate from eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, or remote sensing technologies?
Disjunctive.Answer: eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, remote sensing technologies

Concept Completion.Question: What are the specific challenges faced in collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Where can datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis-desert areas be accessed?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how meteorological data is collected in arid regions to study evapotranspiration?
Example.Answer: In arid regions, meteorological data is collected using automatic weather stations equipped with sensors to measure air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and radiation. For instance, in the HiWATER experiment, data was collected every 10 minutes using a setup that included eddy covariance systems for turbulent fluxes and four-component radiometers for radiation measurements.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert systems?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is crucial for understanding complex processes. The HiWATER experiment addresses this by using hierarchically nested scales and deploying a variety of instruments like eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations across different landscapes.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used in hydrometeorological observations for oasis-desert interactions?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'multi-scale observations' in the context of eco-hydrological studies?
Definition.Answer: Multi-scale observations refer to the data collection strategy that involves capturing eco-hydrological processes at various spatial and temporal scales. This approach is crucial for understanding complex interactions in heterogeneous landscapes, such as oasis-desert systems, and often involves the use of hierarchically nested instruments to gather comprehensive datasets.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems compare with those used for monitoring evapotranspiration using the TSEB model?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems involve multiscale observations with instruments like eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, capturing interactions in various landscapes. In contrast, monitoring evapotranspiration using the TSEB model focuses on ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures and involves thermal infrared imaging and radiometric temperature validation.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data collection methods employed for the hydrometeorological observations ensure accuracy and reliability in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection methods involve a comprehensive setup of stations with various sensors positioned at different heights and depths to capture diverse hydrometeorological parameters. Quality control measures include ensuring consistent data entries, removing duplicates, and filtering out physically implausible readings. This multi-layered approach is designed to handle the complexity and variability inherent in heterogeneous landscapes, such as the oasis-desert systems.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might the integration of multiscale data from remote sensing and ground-based observations enhance the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating multiscale data allows for a comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological processes by capturing both large-scale patterns and localized phenomena. Remote sensing provides spatial coverage and temporal consistency, while ground-based observations offer detailed insights into specific environmental variables. This combination can improve model accuracy and offer more robust predictions of water, energy, and carbon exchanges in complex landscapes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to several factors, including the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy. Errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature can also lead to overestimation of component temperatures, affecting model performance. Additionally, the strong advective environment in these regions adds complexity to accurate estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development is challenged by ecological degradation, such as the drying of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification. These issues are exacerbated by climatic changes and human activities, particularly in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, which are crucial for ecological and socioeconomic stability.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop multiscale datasets for studying eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing multiscale datasets is important because it addresses the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, which is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. These datasets allow for the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, which can provide a comprehensive understanding of oasis-desert interactions and support ecological stability and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals drive the use of high-resolution thermal cameras and isotope techniques in estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using high-resolution thermal cameras and isotope techniques in estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration is to improve the validation of these processes by providing accurate soil and canopy component temperatures. This approach allows for better separation and estimation of soil and vegetation component temperatures, enhancing the accuracy of evapotranspiration modeling in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is there a focus on long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: There is a focus on long-term observations because these data are crucial for understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is significant for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting the ecological security and socioeconomic development of oases, and recognizing oasis–desert interactions to protect ecological stability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can data processing ensure the quality of meteorological and hydrological observations in an oasis-desert system?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure involves data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing. Observational datasets consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Quality control is crucial and includes sensor calibration, data processing, and careful dataset generation. Data from automatic weather stations are averaged over a 10-minute period, and additional parameters such as soil and vegetation are supplemented to enhance data integrity.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to obtain and validate soil and canopy component temperatures in an irrigated agricultural area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil and canopy component temperatures are obtained using a high-resolution thermal camera mounted on a platform. Thermal images are captured approximately every 120 minutes during the daylight hours. The visible and NIR images are classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. The directional brightness temperatures are extracted from thermal images, and thermal infrared temperatures are converted to radiative temperatures using observed long-wave radiation and emissivities. The simulated radiometric temperatures are validated against surface radiometric temperatures recorded by a four-component radiometer.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale eco-hydrological processes captured in a heterogeneous surface using remote sensing and ground observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiscale eco-hydrological processes are captured using a hierarchically nested observational system. This involves installing eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Additionally, an eco-hydrological sensor network measures soil moisture and leaf area index. Remote sensing is conducted using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer. These observations are complemented by synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. The collected data are carefully quality controlled and made available through data centers.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technological setups enable the accurate measurement of evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate measurement of evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes is enabled by using a combination of ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, high-resolution thermal cameras, eddy covariance systems, and stable isotope techniques, as well as a comprehensive setup of meteorological parameters measured at specific heights and frequencies.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple observation scales enhance the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multiple observation scales enhances the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems by employing hierarchically nested scales, which include a sparse network of various landscape observations, superstations, EC towers, AMSs, and high-resolution airborne remote sensing missions. This setup captures multi-scale data critical for studying interactions and processes.

Enablement.Question: What are the technological and methodological advancements that facilitate long-term data collection in arid and semi-arid regions for energy and water vapor exchange studies?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term data collection in arid and semi-arid regions for energy and water vapor exchange studies is facilitated by advancements such as the use of eddy covariance systems, automatic weather stations with frequent measurement intervals, and comprehensive datasets involving hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. These technologies and methodologies ensure robust data collection and quality control over extended periods.

Expectation.Question: Why might the effectiveness of data collection methods be limited in arid regions when measuring evapotranspiration?
Expectation.Answer: The effectiveness of data collection methods in arid regions can be limited due to difficulties in measuring evaporation and transpiration on the ground. Errors in image classification and uncertainties in estimating component temperatures from surface radiometric temperature can contribute to this limitation.

Expectation.Question: What factors contribute to the challenge of observing energy and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems over long periods?
Expectation.Answer: Observing energy and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems over long periods is challenging due to ecological degradation issues such as drying rivers and lakes and land desertification. These factors, along with the need for comprehensive and continuous data collection involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, contribute to the complexity of obtaining reliable long-term observations.

Judgmental.Question: How do researchers evaluate the effectiveness of data collection methods in capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers evaluate the effectiveness of data collection methods by implementing instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, using a combination of intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations. This approach allows for capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes and addressing the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how data quality control is maintained during the collection of meteorological data in such diverse environments.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality control is maintained by ensuring consistent data collection intervals (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with specific indicators, removing duplicate or non-physically plausible data, and using a uniform format for date and time. Additionally, sensor calibration and careful data processing steps are employed to ensure accuracy and reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore different methods for quality control and data processing in the collection of hydrometeorological datasets over heterogeneous land surfaces, including potential challenges faced in arid and semi-arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection and quality control methods include ensuring a consistent data format, removing physically implausible data, and marking questionable data. Challenges in arid regions include image classification errors due to vegetation abundance, resulting in component temperature estimation errors, and atmospheric factors affecting temperature estimations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and analyze potential strategies for enhancing the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation models using ground-based and remote sensing observations in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for enhancing accuracy include using a two-source energy balance model with soil and canopy component temperatures obtained through ground-based measurements and high-resolution thermal cameras. Accurate separation of soil and vegetation component temperatures is crucial for improving model performance, as errors can arise from misclassification of pixels and atmospheric conditions.
